root.pub-comments: "I claim (somewhat tentatively) that PAn [Proto Austronesian] underwent a primary four-way split into Puyuma, Tsou, Rukai and Proto Nuclear Austronesian (PNAn)" (Ross 2009:295).
root.publications: Ross, Malcolm D. 2009. Proto Austronesian verbal morphology: a reappraisal. In K. Alexander Adelaar & Andrew K Pawley (eds.), Austronesian historical linguistics and culture history: a festschrift for Robert Blust, Pacific Linguistics, vol. 601, 295-326. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "The set of innovations […] is complex, and it is improbable that they occurred independently in different languages. Instead, they probably occurred once, in PNAn [Proto Nuclear Austronesian]" (Ross 2009:314).
child.publications: Ross, Malcolm D. 2009. Proto Austronesian verbal morphology: a reappraisal. In K. Alexander Adelaar & Andrew K Pawley (eds.), Austronesian historical linguistics and culture history: a festschrift for Robert Blust, Pacific Linguistics, vol. 601, 295-326. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: Author specifies that the Malayo-Polynesian group contains "all extra-Formosan Austronesian languages (including Yami, which lies within Taiwan's political boundary)" (Ross 2009:316).
child.publications: Ross, Malcolm D. 2009. Proto Austronesian verbal morphology: a reappraisal. In K. child.pub-comments: In a footnote: "The evidence for Northwest Formosan is weak, and I would prefer to treat Saisiyat and Kulon-Pazih as separate subgroups, but this issue lies beyond the scope of this paper" (Ross 2009:316).
child.publications: Ross, Malcolm D. 2009. Proto Austronesian verbal morphology: a reappraisal. In K. Alexander Adelaar & Andrew K Pawley (eds.), Austronesian historical linguistics and culture history: a festschrift for Robert Blust, Pacific Linguistics, vol. 601, 295-326. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "No shared innovations have been found supporting a subgroup containing two or three of Puyuma, Tsou, Rukai and PNAn, and so each is assumed to form a primary subgroup of Austronesian in its own right" (Ross 2009:314).
child.publications: Ross, Malcolm D. 2009. Proto Austronesian verbal morphology: a reappraisal. In K. Alexander Adelaar & Andrew K Pawley (eds.), Austronesian historical linguistics and culture history: a festschrift for Robert Blust, Pacific Linguistics, vol. 601, 295-326. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
